questions.question: A 6-year-old child complaining of pain and swelling is suspected with supracondylar fracture of right hand (Undisplaced). X-ray of right elbow was not significant. What is the next best step in this case?

options.A: Compare with X-ray of left hand
options.B: Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion)
options.C: Closed reduction with K wire fixation Cast

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion) occur just above the elbow joint and can result in pain, swelling, and deformity of the affected arm. The initial evaluation typically involves an X-ray of the elbow to assess the fracture. In this case, if the X-ray of the right elbow is not significant(undisplaced). Therefore, the next best step would be Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab(90 degree flexion). Supracondylar fractures: Mechanism of injury: Supracondylar fractures typically occur due to a fall onto an outstretched hand with an extended arm, causing a significant force to be transmitted to the distal humerus. Common in children: Supracondylar fractures are more common in children, particularly between the ages of 5 and 7 years. Presentation : Patients with a supracondylar fracture often present with pain, swelling, and deformity in the elbow region. There may also be limited range of motion and tenderness upon palpation. Types : Supracondylar fractures can be classified into different types based on the degree of displacement and the involvement of surrounding structures. The most commonly used classification system is the Gartland classification , which includes three types: Type I: Non-displaced or minimally displaced fracture. Type II: Fracture with significant displacement but with intact posterior cortex. Type III: Fracture with complete displacement and loss of alignment. Reference: SCH

questions.question: What type of displacement is most likely observed in a 60-year-old female patient who presents with pain and swelling in her left wrist after falling on an outstretched hand, and exhibits a dinner fork deformity upon examination?

options.A: Proximal and ventral displacement of radius
options.B: Supination and dorsal displacement of radius
options.C: Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna
options.D: Proximal and ventral displacement of ulna

questions.explanation: the distal fragment of the radius is displaced dorsally. At the same time, the wrist is tilted towards the palm of the hand, resulting in the characteristic dinner fork deformity.. Displacement of Radius that may be seen in Colles’ fracture: Dorsal shift Dorsal tilt Lateral shift Lateral tilt Supination Proximal shift Diagnosis is done by X-ray. The most common is Dorsal tilt. Best test to identify colles fracture - styloid process test. Styloid Process Test: Normally the radial styloid process is distal to the ulnar styloid process. In Colles fracture - both radial and ulnar styloid processes are at the same level. Most reliable clinical sign. Management of a Colles' fracture: Closed reduction and below elbow POP cast- “Handshake cast” : Palmar flexion,pronation and ulnar deviation (prevent dorsal displacement). Complications Stiffness of fingers - most common Malunion - next common complication Median nerve - most common nerve injured. One of the very common causes of Carpal tunnel syndrome. Extensor pollicis longus - most common tendon injured. Proximal and ventral displacement of radius (Option A) is reverse colle’s fracture, this would result in a deformity that appears opposite to the dinner fork deformity, with the wrist being angled downwards. Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna (Option C) distal radius fracture would not typically result in displacement of the ulna. Proximal and ventral displacement of ulna (Option D) is also incorrect as this would result in a deformity that appears opposite to the dinner fork deformity, with the wrist angled upwards.

questions.question: Which nerve is most likely to be damaged in cases of anterior shoulder dislocation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Axillary nerve Explanation: Anterior dislocation of the shoulder can result in damage to the axillary nerve. The axillary nerve is a nerve that arises from the brachial plexus and runs along the surgical neck of the humerus. It innervates the deltoid muscle and the teres minor muscle, as well as provides sensory innervation to the skin over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. When the shoulder is dislocated anteriorly, the head of the humerus moves forward and can compress or stretch the axillary nerve, resulting in damage to the nerve. This can cause weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle and sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. The severity of the axillary nerve injury depends on the degree of stretching or compression that occurs during the dislocation. Median nerve (Option B): is most commonly injured in the posterior dislocation of the elbow. It innervates the muscles of the forearm and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the hand. Anterior dislocation of the shoulder is unlikely to directly affect the median nerve. Radial and suprascapular nerves (Options C and D): are unlikely to be damaged in anterior shoulder dislocation. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page 763, 764, 386

questions.question: Match the following fractures with their respective sites. A. Jones fracture B. Bennett's fracture C. March fracture D. Boxer fracture 1. 5th metatarsal 2. 2nd metatarsal 3. 1st metacarpal 4. 5th metacarpal
questions.explanation: the base of the 5th metatarsal. Bennett’s fracture is the intra-articular fracture of the base of 1st metacarpal with subluxation of the trapezio-metacarpal joint. March fracture is a fatigue fracture of the neck of the 2nd metatarsal. Boxer’s fracture, also called Fighters’ fracture is a fracture of the neck of 5th metacarpal Fracture Type Features Treatment Jones fractures Significant adduction force to the foot with a lifted heel (e.g., sudden direction change) Location of injury: 4th/5th metatarsal articulation March Fracture A stress fracture commonly seen in runners, involving the metatarsals due to repetitive overuse . The patient's gradual onset of pain and tenderness after increased running X-ray shows no obvious fracture, but a faint periosteal reaction is seen. Bennett fracture Oblique intra-articular fracture (2 part) of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the metacarpal. It is caused by a longitudinal force applied to the thumb. Treatment: Closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation Open reduction and internal fixation Boxer's fracture Fracture through the neck of the metacarpal (commonly the 5th metacarpal). Cause: Closed fist hits against a hard object Treatment: Mostly conservative

questions.question: An old lady slipped and fell at home. She was diagnosed with a Colles fracture and managed with a POP cast. What is the correct sequence of reduction of the given fracture?

options.A: Traction, POP, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation
options.B: Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP
options.C: Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP
options.D: Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP

questions.explanation: extra-articular. The deformity seen is Dinner fork deformity. Displacements seen are: Impaction of fragments Dorsal displacement Dorsal tilt Lateral displacement Lateral tilt Supination Closed manipulation of Colles’ fracture is by: Traction + Counter traction (by the assistant) ↓ Palmar flexion ↓ Ulnar deviation ↓ POP application Management of a Colles' fracture: Closed reduction and below elbow POP cast- “Handshake cast” : Palmar flexion,pronation and ulnar deviation (prevent dorsal displacement). Complications Stiffness of fingers - most common Malunion - next common complication Median nerve - most common nerve injured. One of the very common causes of Carpal tunnel syndrome. Extensor pollicis longus - most common tendon injured. Options A, C and D are incorrect Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopedics, 10th Edition, Page 797-800

questions.question: A female patient with a history of fall few months back presents with the deformity shown in the image. Probing into history reveals it was managed with traditional treatment. This deformity is likely to be due to?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Extra-articular fracture of wrist. Explanation: The image shows a fracture of the wrist that does not involve the joint space, indicating an extra-articular fracture. Extra-articular fractures occur outside the joint, typically involving the distal radius. They are commonly caused by falls or direct trauma to the wrist. Traditional treatment refers to non-surgical methods of managing the fracture, such as casting or splinting. Intra-articular fracture of the wrist (Option A): Intra-articular fractures involve the joint surface. The image does not indicate involvement of the joint. Boxer's Fracture (Option C): Boxer's fracture typically refers to a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone, often resulting from punching or striking an object with a closed fist. Barton's Fracture (Option D): Barton's fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius, usually involving displacement or subluxation of the radiocarpal joint. Reference: Extra-articular fractures

questions.question: Fishtail deformity is seen in fracture of
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Distal end of humerus Explanation: Fishtail deformity is commonly associated with a fracture of distal end of humerus. It is due to separation of articular surface of distal humerus into two fragments resembling the shape of fishtail. Supracondylar Fractures Mechanism of injury Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH) Location Humerus fractures just above the condyles. Displacements The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by Posterior shift (Due to Impaction) Posterior Tilt Proximal shift Medial shift/ Tilt Internal rotation Types Type 1: Undisplaced fracture Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex. Clinical Presentation Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the hand of benediction sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected. Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity) The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign) X-ray Findings Three bony parts relationship is maintained. Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads. Disturbed teardrop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion. Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail . Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment. Management Based on the type of fracture Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion. Displaced fractures Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture) Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture) In Late presentation with swelling Dunlop traction (skin) Smith traction (skeletal) Complications Early complications Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery) Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve ) Delayed complications Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion) Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome. Elbow stiffness Myositis ossificans.

questions.question: What is the most specific test used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Durkan's test Explanation: Carpal Compression Test or Median Compression Test or Durkan’s test is a diagnostic test of carpal tunnel syndrome. It involves applying direct pressure over the carpal tunnel for 30 seconds . If the patient experiences numbness, pain, or paresthesia in the distribution of the median nerve, the test is considered positive. Carpal tunnel syndrome Definition Compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist Symptoms Numbness, tingling in thumb, index, and middle fingers Pain in hand and wrist Weakness in grip Symptoms often worse at night and improve during the day. Advanced cases may lead to constant symptoms, hand weakness, clumsiness, and muscle atrophy. Structures Affected Median Nerve : Compressed within the carpal tunnel, leading to symptoms and signs. Flexor Tendons : The nine flexor tendons passing through the carpal tunnel can become inflamed, further compressing the median nerve. Structures Spared Thenar Eminence : Sensory loss generally spares this area because its nerve (palmar sensory cutaneous nerve) bypasses the carpal tunnel. Clinical Signs Weakness: Notable weakness in thumb abduction and opposition. Atrophy : Possible atrophy of the thenar eminence in advanced cases. Sensory Loss : Loss typically affects the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the fourth digit). Causes Idiopathic- commonest cause Inflammatory causes- Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis Post-traumatic causes- Bone thickening after a Colles' fracture Endocrine causes- Myxoedema, Acromegaly Diagnostic Tests Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) - primary diagnostic test Electromyography (EMG) Carpal Compression Test/ Durkan test : Diagnostic test. Positive if pain/paresthesias occur during pressure application over the carpal tunnel. Phalen Test : Positive if pain/paresthesias arise during wrist flexion. (Option B ruled out) Tinel Test: Positive if tapping over the carpal tunnel elicits symptoms. (Option C ruled out) Treatment Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification Corticosteroid injections Surgical: Carpal tunnel release (for severe or refractory cases) Two-point discrimination (Option D) : This test assesses sensory function, specifically the ability to distinguish between two separate points of stimulation. While a loss of two-point discrimination can be a sign of carpal tunnel syndrome, this test is more general for sensory assessment and not as specific for diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome as Durkan's test. Reference: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf Carpal Compression Test - Physiopedia

questions.question: Identify the following fracture:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Monteggia Fracture Explanation: The presented X-ray findings indicate a fracture of the upper third of the ulna indicating a Monteggia fracture, also called a treacherous fracture. While the ulna fracture is clearly evident on the X-ray, the associated dislocation of the radial head may be overlooked. Monteggia fracture Site Fracture of the proximal third of the ulna is accompanied by a radial head dislocation . Cause Fall on an outstretched hand Mechanism Complications Nerve injury (Posterior Interosseous Nerve) Malunion Non-union Cubitus valgus. Radio ulnar synostosis (Type 4 Monteggia Fracture) Myositis Ossificans. Colles Fracture (Option A) involves a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement, often due to a fall on an outstretched hand. This does not involve the ulna or radial head dislocation, making it different from a Monteggia fracture. Barton's Fracture (Option C) refers to a fracture of the distal radius involving the radiocarpal joint (articular surface), often accompanied by dislocation of the wrist joint. It is distinct from the Monteggia fracture, which involves the ulna and radial head. None of the Above (Option D): This option is incorrect because the fracture shown is clearly a Monteggia fracture, involving the proximal ulna and radial head dislocation.

questions.question: A 23 year old male epileptic patient presented with pain in right shoulder region. Examination revealed that right upper limb was abducted and externally rotated and the movements could not be performed. Which of the following is most likely diagnosed
questions.explanation: anterior shoulder dislocation (type: subglenoid dislocation). Types of Shoulder dislocations: Aspects Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation (Option D) Inferior dislocation (Option B) Frequency Most common Not very common Rare Mechanism of Injury Fall on an outstretched hand with an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. Occurs during seizures or convulsions . A fall onto a flexed, adducted arm . A direct impact to the anterior aspect of the shoulder . A fall onto an outstretched hand . Also called luxatio erecta. Result from a severe hyper-abduction force. Clinical presentation Pain, swelling and movement restriction. Tests Duga’s test, Hamilton ruler test and Regimental badge test. Callaway’s test and Regimental badge test Bryant’s test Arm Position Abduction and external rotation Adduction and internal rotation Arm locked in hyperabduction with the hand positioned above the head. X-ray Findings The humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position). "Hill-Sachs lesion" (compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head). The humeral head is displaced posteriorly, appearing closer to the scapula. ‘Light bulb sign ’(humeral head appears rounded due to internal rotation). ‘Rim sign’ (widening of the glenohumeral joint space). ‘Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion’ (compression fracture on the anteromedial humeral head). The humeral head is displaced inferiorly below the glenoid cavity. Management Reduction techniques: Kocher's method (Most commonly used) Hippocrates method Stimson’s technique Reduction and immobility, followed by active exercises. Closed reduction Open reduction if soft tissue injuries are present Re-examination after reduction to avoid neurovascular injuries. Complications Early: Neurovascular injuries Rotator cuff tear Delayed: Recurrence Stiffness Unreduced dislocation Recurrence Unreduced dislocation Neurovascular injuries Recurrence Unreduced dislocation Anterior Shoulder dislocation Subtypes Subglenoid : The humeral head lies below the glenoid fossa. Subclavicular : The humeral head is displaced beneath the clavicle. Intrathoracic : The humeral head dislocates into the thoracic cavity, which is rare. Subcoracoid : The humeral head lies below the coracoid process. Clinical findings Loss of the deltoid contour (loss of shoulder roundness) The shoulder is extended, abducted and externally rotated . Clinical tests Duga’s test is the inability to touch the opposite shoulder. Hamilton ruler test is where the gap between the ruler and the arm is lost. Callaway’s test is increased girth of the axilla on the dislocated side. Bryant’s Test is where the anterior axillary fold is displaced downward on the affected side. Regiment batch sign is loss of sensation due to axillary nerve damage. Imaging X-ray reveals that the humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, often under the coracoid process ("subcoracoid" position) An MRI is necessary to assess soft-tissue injuries and identify Bankart and Hill-Sachs lesions, which are complications of shoulder dislocations and increase the risk of recurrence due to joint instability. Management Kocher's method (Most common method) is the

questions.question: Three point bony relationship has a diagnostic value in:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Elbow Fracture Explanation: The three-point bony relationship refers to the alignment of three specific landmarks in the elbow joint: the capitellum, the radial head, and the olecranon process. When these three points are aligned properly, it indicates that the elbow joint is in its normal anatomical position. In the context of elbow fractures, assessing the three-point bony relationship is crucial in determining the presence of a fracture and evaluating its displacement or dislocation. Any disruption in the alignment of these three points may indicate a fracture or joint injury. Elbow Fractures: Treatment options for elbow fractures depend on various factors, including the type and severity of the fracture, patient age, and overall health. Treatment may involve: Nonsurgical Treatment: Some fractures can be managed with immobilization, such as casting or splinting, followed by a period of rest and rehabilitation. Surgical Treatment: Certain fractures may require surgical intervention, such as open reduction (realignment of the fractured bones) and internal fixation (use of screws, plates, or rods to hold the bones in place). Rehabilitation : After treatment, rehabilitation plays a crucial role in the recovery process. Physical therapy and exercises help restore strength, range of motion, and function to the elbow joint. Reference: Elbow fractures

questions.question: A 25 year old man fell down while running. He tried to sustain the fall on his elbow resulting in the injury shown below.What will be the appropriate management of the following fracture?

options.C: Close reduction with Tension band wiring
options.D: Immobilization of elbow, Above elbow plaster slab with 30 degree flexion

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Immobilization of elbow, Above elbow plaster slab with 30 degree flexion. olecranon fracture. This is usually seen in adults. It results from a direct injury, as in a fall onto the point of the elbow. Pathoanatomy - The proximal fragment may be pulled proximally by the attached triceps muscle, thus creating a gap at the fracture site. The fracture may be one of the three types: Type I: Crack without displacement of fragments. Type Il : Clean break with separation of fragments. Type III: Comminuted fracture. Treatment : It depends upon the type of fracture: Type l: A crack without displacement is treated by immobilising the elbow in an above-elbow plaster slab in 30 degree of flexion After 3 weeks the plaster is removed and elbow exercises begun. Type II: A clean break with separation of the fragments is treated by open reduction and internal fixation using technique of/tension-band wiring is not possible to keep the fragments together in the plaster alone because of the constant pull exerted by the triceps. Type III: A comminuted fracture, if not separated, is treated in a plaster: slab as in type-1, but if the fragments are separated/tension-band wiring excision of the fragments may be

questions.question: The diagnosis of the given image
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Scapho Lunate Instability Explanation: Scapholunate instability refers to an abnormal movement or separation of the scaphoid and lunate bones, which are two of the carpal bones in the wrist. This instability can be caused by injury or ligamentous damage, leading to improper alignment and movement of these bones. Mechanism of Injury - Fall on an outstretched hand- Repetitive wrist trauma or overuse. Clinical Presentation: Wrist pain or tenderness Swelling or instability in the wrist Signs of chronic instability may include a dinner fork deformity or widening of the scapholunate joint Physical Examination: Scaphoid shift test: Palpable clunk or abnormal movement of the scaphoid bone with ulnar deviation and wrist flexion Watson test: Painful clunk or subluxation of the scaphoid during radial or ulnar deviation of the wrist Terry Thomas sign: Increased scapholunate space on radiographic imaging, indicating abnormal alignment between the scaphoid and lunate bones Radiographic Evaluation: X-rays: Routine radiographs may reveal widening of the scapholunate joint space (>3mm) on a lateral view (Terry Thomas sign).

questions.question: Postmenopausal woman slipped and fell down on an outstretched hand in the washroom. X-ray of her distal forearm is given below. Diagnose the following condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Colle's Fracture Explanation: Postmenopausal women are prone to develop osteoporosis due to decreased secretion of estrogen from ovaries. Women suffering from osteoporosis are prone to Colles fracture, which is a type of wrist fracture. This type of fracture usually happens after falling on an outstretched hand. The given x-ray shows fracture of the distal end of radius at cortico- cancellous junction. Fracture Name Characteristic Findings Sites Involved Special History Colles Fracture Dorsal displacement of the distal radius. Distal radius Falling on an outstretched hand Smith's Fracture Volar displacement of the distal radius. Distal radius Falling on a flexed wrist Monteggia Fracture Proximal ulnar shaft fracture with radial head dislocation. Proximal ulna, radial head Direct blow to the ulna or forearm Galeazzi Fracture Distal radial shaft fracture with distal radioulnar joint dislocation. Distal radius, radioulnar joint Fall on an outstretched hand with an ulnar deviation

questions.question: Identify the given fracture?
questions.explanation: defined as a distal radius fracture with dorsal comminution, dorsal angulation, dorsal displacement, radial shortening, and an associated ulnar styloid fracture . Incorrect Options: Option B: Monteggia Fracture- The Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal ulna associated with dislocation of the radial head . Option C: Galeazzi Fracture - A Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the middle to distal third of the radius associated with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint Option D: None of the above- This option is incorrect

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect about perilunate dislocation ?

options.A: Lunate is dislocated anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remains in position
options.B: Lunate remains in position but rest other dislocate dorsally
options.D: Tavernier's manoeuvre is used for closed reduction

questions.explanation: Perilunate dislocation involves the disruption of the normal alignment between the carpal bones in the wrist. In perilunate dislocation, the lunate bone remains in its anatomical position, while the other carpal bones, including the scaphoid, triquetrum, and other adjacent bones, dislocate dorsally Therefore, the statement that the lunate is dislocated anteriorly while the rest of the carpals remain in position is incorrect. Incorrect Options: Option B - Lunate remains in position but rest other dislocate dorsally - In perilunate dislocation, the lunate bone remains in its anatomical position, while the other carpal bones, including the scaphoid, triquetrum, and other adjacent bones, dislocate dorsally. This displacement can result from high-energy trauma or significant wrist hyperextension. Option C - Involves median nerve injury- Perilunate dislocation can cause compression or injury to the median nerve. The median nerve runs through the carpal tunnel, which can be affected by the dislocation and subsequent displacement of the carpal bones. Median nerve injury can lead to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, or weakness in the hand and fingers. Option D - Tavernier's manoeuvre is used for closed reduction- Tavernier's maneuver, or closed reduction, is a technique used to reposition the dislocated carpal bones in perilunate dislocation. It involves applying traction and manipulation to guide the displaced carpal bones back into their proper alignment. This maneuver is commonly employed to reduce the dislocation before further stabilization or surgical intervention. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Identify the following device.
questions.explanation: wrist in a neutral or slightly extended position. It is typically used for conditions such as carpal tunnel syndrome, wrist sprains, and tendon injuries. The splint extends along the volar aspect of the forearm and supports the wrist in a dorsiflexed position while allowing finger movements. Incorrect Options: Option B - Colles' cast: Colles' cast is a type of cast used for the treatment of distal radius fractures. It is a circumferential cast that extends from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, immobilizing the wrist and forearm. Option C - Knuckle bender splint: Knuckle bender splint is a finger splint used to provide extension support to the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint of the finger. Option D - Dynamic finger splint: Dynamic finger splint is a splint that allows controlled movement of the finger joints while providing support and protection. It is often used in the rehabilitation of finger injuries or after surgeries. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The X-ray image of a patient presented to the casualty is given below. How will you manage this case?
questions.explanation: displaced. Tension band wiring (TBW) is the standard treatment for simple, transverse, or minimally comminuted olecranon fractures . TBW converts tensile forces from the triceps into compressive forces at the fracture site during elbow movement, promoting healing. Olecranon Fracture Aspect Details Anatomy Olecranon is part of the proximal ulna and serves as the insertion for the triceps Mechanism of Injury Direct trauma or fall on outstretched hand with elbow flexed Clinical Features Pain, swelling, inability to extend the elbow X-ray Findings Fracture line at the olecranon, often transverse or comminuted Non-operative Treatment Immobilization in nondisplaced fractures (rare) Operative Treatment Depends on fracture type: Tension band wiring for transverse/simple fractures Plating for comminuted or unstable fractures Nailing (Option A): Incorrect because intramedullary nailing is not used for olecranon fractures; it’s suited for long bone diaphyseal fractures (e.g., femur, tibia). Plating (Option B): Incorrect for simple fractures; plating is reserved for comminuted or unstable olecranon fractures, not first-line in simple transverse ones. Knee splint (Option D): Incorrect because this is irrelevant to the elbow; used for lower limb injuries.

questions.question: Identify the fracture shown in the image?
questions.explanation: fracture which is evident by the marked indentation at the site of Radial head. Radial head fracture is caused mostly due to indirect trauma, with most resulting from a fall on an abducted arm with minimal or moderate flexion of the elbow joint. Radial Head Fractures: Definition A fracture of the radial head, the upper part of the radius that articulates with the humerus and ulna at the elbow joint. Causes Most commonly caused by a fall onto an outstretched hand (FOOSH) Direct trauma or a blow to the elbow MVA (Motor Vehicle Accidents) or sports injuries Types of Fractures Type I: Non-displaced fracture (usually treated conservatively) Type II: Displaced fracture with a single fragment (may require surgical intervention) Type III: Comminuted (multiple fragments, often requiring surgical reconstruction or replacement) Symptoms Pain and tenderness at the lateral aspect of the elbow Swelling and bruising around the elbow joint Limited range of motion, with flexion and extension Difficulty supination and pronation Diagnosis Tenderness, swelling, and limited motion. X-rays: Used to classify the type and displacement of the fracture. CT scan: Used for more complex fractures. Treatment Options Conservative management: For non-displaced (Type I) fractures. Surgical management: For displaced (Type II) or comminuted (Type III) fractures- radial head fixation, replacement (arthroplasty), or excision. Complications Loss of elbow range of motion Chronic pain Elbow instability Post-traumatic arthritis Stiffness or deformity of the joint

questions.question: Which of the following fractures can cause a deformity as shown in the image below?
questions.explanation: especially in children, can lead to malunion and the characteristic "gunstock deformity" (cubitus varus), where the arm angles inward when extended. This deformity is due to improper alignment during healing. Incorrect Options: Option A - Lateral condyle of humerus fracture: This fracture affects the lateral part of the distal humerus. It can lead to complications like malunion, which may cause a "cubitus valgus" deformity but does not typically result in the "gunstock deformity" (cubitus varus). Option B - Monteggia fracture: This is a fracture of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head at the elbow. It primarily affects the forearm and elbow stability, but it does not typically cause the "gunstock deformity." Option D - Shaft of humerus fracture: A fracture of the humeral shaft can cause issues like nerve injury or nonunion, but it does not typically result in the "gunstock deformity." Reference: .

questions.question: Linear growth of bone is disturbed when a fracture occurs in which of the following locations?
questions.explanation: epiphyseal plate (growth plate), as this area is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones. Fractures in the epiphyseal plate can lead to growth disturbances and potential deformities. Incorrect Options: Option A - Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the end part of a long bone, which is primarily involved in joint formation and can affect the bone's shape and function. While fractures here can cause issues with joint function and alignment, they do not directly disrupt linear bone growth. Option B - Diaphysis: The diaphysis is the central shaft of a long bone. Fractures here affect the bone's structural integrity and stability but do not directly interfere with linear bone growth. Option C - Metaphysis: The metaphysis is the region between the epiphysis and diaphysis and is involved in the growth and remodeling of bone. Fractures in this area can impact bone growth due to its proximity to the growth plate, but they do not directly involve the growth plate itself.

questions.question: Which classification is used for the following fracture, and what is its stage?
questions.explanation: fractures of the humerus in children. A Gartland type 3 fracture is characterized by complete displacement of the fracture with no cortical contact between the fragments. This type of fracture is unstable and often requires surgical intervention. Incorrect Options: Option B - Gartland 2 : This is also part of the Gartland classification, describing a supracondylar fracture where there is partial displacement, but some cortical contact is still maintained. It is less severe than Gartland 3. Option C - Salter-Harris 3 : The Salter-Harris classification is used for physeal (growth plate) fractures, not supracondylar fractures. A type 3 fracture involves a fracture through the growth plate and the epiphysis, extending into the joint. Option D - Salter-Harris 2 : This classification describes a fracture through the growth plate and metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis. Like option C, it is not relevant to supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

questions.question: Identify the fracture:
questions.explanation: commonly seen in blunt head injuries. Depressed Fracture Comminuted Fracture Gutter Fracture (Option D) Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain. Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks). The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury. Variants: Elevated Fracture : One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe. Pond Fracture : Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade. Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments. Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries). It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures). Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures. In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced. A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due

questions.question: A 17-year-old boy who fell on an outstretched hand is now experiencing pain and swelling at the base of the thumb. Which bone is most likely fractured?
questions.explanation: tenderness in the anatomical snuff box (the depression at the base of the thumb). They are particularly common among young adults. Scaphoid fracture Site Waist of scaphoid (most common) Distal pole (Least common) Proximal pole (high risk for avascular necrosis) Mechanism of injury Typically caused by a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) with the wrist in dorsiflexion. Clinical features It is more common in young adults , particularly athletes. Pain and tenderness localised to the anatomical snuffbox (the depression between the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and the abductor pollicis longus/extensor pollicis brevis). Swelling and reduced range of motion at the wrist. X-ray There is a visible fracture line at the waist of the scaphoid, with possible cortical disruption or displacement; avascular necrosis may later appear as sclerosis in the proximal pole. Management Immobilisation by scaphoid cast (3-4 months) Complications Avascular necrosis (more common in the proximal pole) Humpback deformity (displaced Scaphoid fracture) Delayed and non-union Wrist osteoarthritis Lunate (Options A) involves hyperextension or compression of a preexisting abnormal lunate. The lunate bone comes out to lie in front of other carpal bones (while in perilunate dislocation, lunate remains in its place and the other carpal bones dislocate around it dorsally). Pisiform (Options C) is a rare fracture that can result from a direct blow, leading to comminuted fractures, or from an indirect force due to an avulsion or pull of the flexor carpi ulnaris tendon. Trapezoid (Options D) is rare due to a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.question: Identify the fracture?
A 7 year old boy is brought to the OPD. He fell on his outstretched arm while riding on his cycle. Clinical examination findings are presented in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Dorsal displacement supracondylar fracture of humerus
options.C: Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.explanation: a cubitus varus deformity, with a reversal of the carrying angle of the arm. Malunion of a supracondylar humerus fracture can result in cubitus varus or gunstock deformity in which the normal carrying angle of the arm is reversed and the forearm deviates to the midline when the elbow is extended. Supracondylar Fractures Mechanism of injury Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH) Location Humerus fractures just above the condyles. Displacements The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by Posterior shift (Due to Impaction) Posterior Tilt Proximal shift Medial shift/ Tilt Internal rotation Types Type 1: Undisplaced fracture Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex. Clinical Presentation Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the "hand of benediction" sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected. Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity) The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign) X-ray Findings Three bony parts relationship is maintained. Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads. Disturbed tear drop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion. Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail . Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment. Management Based on the type of fracture Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion. Displaced fractures Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture) Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture) In Late presentation with swelling Dunlop traction (skin) Smith traction (skeletal) Complications Early complications Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery) Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve ) Delayed complications Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion) (Option C) Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome. Elbow stiffness Myositis ossificans. Dorsal displacement supracondylar fracture of humerus (Option A) occurs when the dorsal fragment is displaced either posteromedially or posterolaterally. It does not cause a varus deformity. Undisplaced supracondylar fracture (Option B) there is no displacement of the posterior and anterior cortex. It does not cause a

questions.question: All of the following is seen in the terrible triad of elbow, except.

options.D: Fracture of the coronoid process of ulna

questions.explanation: "terrible triad of the elbow" except fracture of the olecranon. Terrible Triad of the Elbow: It refers to a specific injury pattern involving three components, commonly seen in elbow dislocations, particularly after trauma: Posterior elbow dislocation (Option A ruled out) Fracture of the radial head (Option B ruled out) Fracture of the coronoid process (Option D ruled out) Mechanism of Injury: Typically results from a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow slightly flexed. A valgus twist can lead to a posterolateral dislocation. Treatment: The standard treatment involves reduction under anaesthesia, followed by immobilisation in an above-elbow cast. Reference: John Ebnezar and Rakesh John, Textbook of Orthopedics, 5th Edition, Page 142 Maheshwari Essential Orthopedics, 5th Edition, Page 105

questions.question: In which of the following fractures does the three point bony relationship is maintained?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Supracondylar fracture Explanation: Supracondylar fracture does not alter the three point bony relationship. Landmarks of three-point bony relationship: Medial epicondyle Lateral epicondyle Olecranon process Three-point bony relationship is deranged in, Lateral/Medial epicondyle fracture humerus (Option A & B) Elbow dislocation (Option C) Intercondylar fracture humerus Olecranon fracture Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4175857

questions.question: What is the name of the test performed in the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Allen's test Explanation: Image shows Allen’s test , used to evaluate the patency of radial and ulnar arteries supplying the hand. Allen's test: The examiner compresses both arteries at the wrist while the patient clenches their fist to drain blood from the hand. Subsequently, pressure on one artery is released, and the return of hand colour is observed. A rapid colour return indicates an adequate blood supply from that artery. It ensures an adequate collateral circulation and is especially useful before procedures such as arterial blood gas sampling or harvesting the radial artery for grafting. Incorrect Options: Adson test (Option B): Adson's test is a provocative test for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome accompanied by compression of the subclavian artery by a cervical rib or tightened anterior and middle scalene muscles. Barbeau test (Option C): The Barbeau test is another method for assessing the patency of the arterial palmar arch . It utilizes pulse oximetry and plethysmography to assess the palmar arches, so this choice is incorrect. Homan's test (Option D): The Homan's test is a physical examination procedure used to diagnose Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) . A positive Homan’s sign in the presence of other clinical signs may be a quick indicator of DVT, so this choice is incorrect.

questions.question: In the emergency room, a 40-year-old male patient arrived with a complaint of pain and swelling in the right shoulder region following a fall. The patient's X-ray indicates a tear in which of the following ligaments?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Both the above Explanation: Above X-ray indicates grade-III injury of the Acromioclavicular joint as per Rockwood classification. In grade-III injury, both coracoclavicular and acromioclavicular ligaments are disrupted. Acromioclavicular joint injuries: Description Acute acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury, commonly following direct trauma; includes sprains, subluxations, and dislocations. Mechanism of Injury Fall on the shoulder with arm adducted leading to ligament strain or tear. Severe forces may cause complete dislocation. Classification Type I: AC ligament sprain; joint remains undisplaced. Type II: AC ligaments torn; joint subluxated with slight clavicle elevation. Type III: AC and coracoclavicular ligaments torn ; joint dislocated, visible step deformity. (Option C) Type IV: Posterior clavicle displacement. Type V: Marked upward clavicle displacement. Type VI: Inferior clavicle displacement beneath the coracoid. Clinical Features Signs: Pain, bruising, and tenderness at the injury site. Visible ‘step’ in cases of dislocation. Movement: Limited shoulder movement with severe pain in dislocation. X-ray Views: Anteroposterior, cephalic tilt, and axillary views are recommended. Stress view may differentiate Type II vs Type III. Stress View: Measure the distance between the coracoid and clavicle; >50% difference indicates dislocation. Treatment Sprains/Subluxations: Rest in a sling, pain subsides within a week, followed by shoulder exercises. Dislocations: Techniques include ligament reconstruction or clavicle excision. Post-surgery Rehab: Elbow/forearm exercises day after surgery, shoulder movements 2 weeks later. Avoid strenuous lifting for 4–6 months.

questions.question: Which of the following ribs is fractured in the X-ray given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 6 Explanation: The X-ray in the question displays a fracture at the 6th rib on the left side . To count ribs: Start counting from the costo-vertebral junction. Locate the first rib and trace its outline from posterior to anterior aspect. Immediately below it you will find the second rib. Similarly you can count the rest of the ribs on the radiograph. Most rib fractures can be diagnosed as discontinuity in the outline of the rib on the radiograph. Some rib fractures (especially those of the lateral part of the ribs) may not be visible on a PA view and may need an oblique view. In doubtful cases, a CT Chest may resolve the query. In clinical practice, rib fractures are diagnosed using clinical and radiological findings.

questions.question: An 11-year-old patient presents with an outward angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm . The patient reports occasional discomfort and limitation in the range of motion of the affected arm. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: forearm in relation to the upper arm. It typically results from a malunion of the distal humerus after a fracture, causing the forearm to deviate away from the midline of the body. Incorrect options: Option A - Cubitus varus: This condition involves an inward angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm. It is seen after a fracture of the distal humerus in children. In cubitus varus, the forearm is deviated towards the midline of the body. Option C - Gunstock deformity: This is often used interchangeably with cubitus varus. It refers to an inward angulation of the forearm due to a malunion of the distal humerus after a fracture. The forearm appears bent, resembling the

questions.question: What condition is shown in the image?
questions.explanation: sign for proximal biceps tendon rupture. Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following nerve is damaged in the picture of the patient given below?
questions.explanation: muscles that extend the wrist and fingers, as well as sensory innervation to the back of the hand. Damage to the radial nerve can result in a condition known as "wrist drop," where the muscles that control wrist extension become weakened or paralyzed. This leads to difficulty lifting the wrist and fingers, and the hand may hang down in a limp or dropped position. Incorrect options: Option B - Ulnar nerve: Ulnar nerve supplies motor function to the muscles of the hand responsible for fine motor movements and also provides sensory innervation to the little finger and part of the ring finger. Damage to the ulnar nerve can lead to issues such as "claw hand," where the muscles controlling finger flexion are affected, causing a characteristic claw-like hand deformity. Option C - Median nerve: Median nerve innervates muscles that control flexion of the wrist and fingers, as well as providing sensory innervation to the palm and fingers. Damage to the median nerve can cause symptoms such as pain,

questions.question: What does a positive Trendelenburg gait not indicate in terms of involvement among the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sciatic nerve Explanation: Positive trendelenburg gait indicates ipsilateral Superior gluteal nerve palsy, which supplies Hip abductors i.e. Gluetus medius and gluteus minimus. The superior gluteal nerve is a direct branch of the sacral plexus and is not related to the sciatic nerve. Trendelenberg sign: When the body's weight is balanced on one leg, the gluteal muscles on the supported side help elevate the opposite, unsupported side of the pelvis. However, if there is a malfunction in the abductor mechanism, the Sound side sinks , which is referred to as a positive Trendelenburg sign (uncompensated). This sign indicates issues with hip abductors, such as paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus ; problems with the fulcrum, including congenital or pathological hip dislocations; and concerns related to body weight, such as an unhealed fracture of the femoral neck. When patients with the gluteus medius and minimus paralysis walk, they have a characteristic lurching gait ie, during the single leg supporting phase of walking, there is leaning of the trunk to the affected side known as the compensated Trendelenburg sign . Duck waddling gait is seen when both the sides are affected. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page 548

questions.question: A patient presents with a tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and the labrum. What is the likely diagnosis for this type of lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bankart's lesion Explanation: Damage of the anterior structures such as the capsule and labrum- tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the capsule and the labrum is called the Bankart lesion. Bankart and Hill-Sachs lesion: Bankart lesion (Option B) Hill-Sachs lesion (Option A) Tear in anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum Posterolateral defect in head of the humerus (Bony defect)

questions.question: A 10-year-old patient presented to the Outpatient Department (OPD) with an u pper limb deformity. An X-ray image is provided. What is the most probable fracture responsible for this deformity?
questions.explanation: children, particularly in the elbow region. They occur just above the condyle of the humerus, which is the bony prominence at the lower end of the upper arm bone. These fractures can result in a characteristic deformity known as "Gartland Type III" or "posteromedial angulation" deformity. The deformity in a supracondylar fracture typically presents with the following features: Angulation: There is an abnormal bending or angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm. Displacement: The distal fragment (lower arm bone) moves posteriorly or towards the back of the arm, causing a noticeable deformity. Swelling and pain: The affected elbow may also exhibit swelling, tenderness, and pain. Incorrect Options: Option B - Olecranon Fracture: An olecranon fracture refers to a fracture of the bony prominence at the back of the elbow, called the olecranon process. This fracture typically results from a direct blow or fall on the elbow. While an olecranon fracture can cause pain, swelling, and limited movement of the elbow, it does not typically cause the characteristic deformity described in the question. The deformity associated with an olecranon fracture usually involves a visible gap or step-off at the back of the

questions.question: While performing a Histamine test on an individual with an injury to the trunk of brachial plexus , you can expect ___________. → wheal → Surrounding flare → Wheal without surrounding flare → Wheal with exaggerated surrounding flare
questions.explanation: → Wheal without surrounding flare → Wheal without surrounding flare: Central capillary dilation → Wheal without surrounding flare: In certain conditions where there is an impairment in the axon reflex or sympathetic vasoconstrictor response, such as in some neurological disorders or nerve injurie s, the surrounding flare component may be absent. In such cases, the individual may still exhibit central capillary dilation and the formation of a wheal, but the surrounding redness and warmth seen in a normal response will not be present. Incorrect Options: Option A - Central capillary dilation → Wheal → Surrounding flare: This sequence describes the typical response observed in a normal individual during the histamine test . Histamine, when applied to the skin, causes central capillary dilation, leading to increased blood flow in the area. This is followed by the formation of a wheal, which is a localized swelling due to fluid extravasation caused by increased vascular permeability. Finally, there is a surrounding flare, which refers to the extension of redness and warmth beyond the immediate area of the wheel. The surrounding flare is a result of the axon reflex, which involves the release of neuropeptides and the dilation of blood vessels mediated by the sympathetic nervous system. Option C - Central capillary dilation → Wheal with exaggerated surrounding flare: This option suggests an exaggerated response to histamine, where there is an excessive surrounding flare in addition to central capillary dilation and wheal formation. This exaggerated response may be observed in certain conditions characterized by increased vascular reactivity, such as urticaria or allergic reactions. Option D - Absent Triple Response: The Triple Response refers to the sequence of central capillary dilation, wheal formation, and surrounding flare observed in a normal response to the histamine test. If all three components of the Triple Response are absent or not observed, it indicates an abnormal or impaired response, which could be indicative of certain pathological conditions or neurological abnormalities . Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 25-year-old man involved in a fight injured his finger and presented with the deformity as shown in the following image. His X-ray is normal. The most appropriate management of the given condition at this stage is:

options.C: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.explanation: drop finger. Results from injury to the extensor tendon of the terminal phalanx. Treatment: An acute mallet finger should be splinted with a Mallet Finger splint for 8 weeks - Best management. Smilies cast - outdated treatment. Surgery is not advised even if there is fracture-dislocation. Fowler's central slip tenotomy: Plastic surgery for old and neglected Mallet fingers. Done for old lesions interfering with hand functions. Splinting the finger in hyperextension is a common approach for managing certain types of finger injuries, particularly those involving extensor tendon injuries. This technique helps to keep the finger in an extended position, preventing flexion contractures and promoting healing of the extensor tendon. It's important to note that a normal X-ray does not exclude the possibility of soft tissue injuries, such as tendon or ligament damage. If the clinical examination suggests a potential flexor or extensor tendon injury, appropriate management should be initiated, even if the X-ray appears normal Incorrect Options: Option A - Splint the finger in flexion: Splinting the finger in flexion is typically indicated for injuries involving the flexor tendon or flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) avulsion. This

questions.question: A patient presents to the emergency department after he fell on his outstretched hand. An X-ray was performed and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This is characteristic of a Galeazzi fracture. Galeazzi fracture involves a fracture of the radius bone along with disruption of the distal radioulnar joint. It typically occurs as a result of a fall with an outstretched hand with an axial load. The fracture pattern involves the junction of the distal and middle third of the radius, while the dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint occurs due to disruption of the interosseous membrane. Incorrect Options: Option A - Colle's Fracture - Colle's fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation. It does not involve dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. Option B - Rolando's Fracture - Rolando's fracture is a comminuted fracture of the base of the thumb, typically resulting from high-energy trauma. It is not applicable to the given X-ray. Option D - Monteggia Fracture - Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna along with dislocation of the radial head. It does not match the findings in the provided X-ray. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The test performed in the following image is
questions.explanation: collateral circulation in the hand. It is typically conducted before arterial puncture or surgical procedures involving the hand. Allen's test: This test involves compressing both the radial and ulnar arteries while the patient clenches and releases their hand. The release of pressure from each artery is done separately to observe the return of colour, indicating the adequacy of collateral circulation. Incorrect Options: Option B - Roos test: The Roos test, also known as the elevated arm stress test, is performed to evaluate thoracic outlet syndrome. It involves asking the patient to open and close their hands rapidly while holding their arms elevated. Option C - Adson's test: Adson's test is used to assess the presence of thoracic outlet syndrome. It involves palpating the radial pulse while the patient rotates their head and extends their neck. Option D - Wright test: There is no widely recognized medical test referred to as the "Wright test." It is not a known test in the context of medical examinations or diagnostics. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Identify the following fracture?
questions.explanation: the ulna (usually the proximal or middle third). - Dislocation of the radial head. Monteggia Fracture is a type of forearm fracture involving a fracture of the proximal or middle third of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head. Incorrect Options: Option A - Colles Fracture : This option is incorrect Option C - Barton's Fracture: This option is incorrect Option D - None of the above: This option is incorrect

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. She was a non-restrained passenger in a car. She has pain in her neck and difficulty in neck movements. She has no associated neurological deficits. A neck collar is applied to protect the spinal cord. An X-ray of the neck is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: vertebra, which is known as a Hangman fracture. It is typically caused by severe hyperextension and distraction forces, commonly seen in motor vehicle accidents. Hangman fractures are unstable injuries that involve the C2 vertebra and can lead to significant spinal instability. Treatment: The treatment of Hangman fractures depends on the type and stability of the fracture, as well as the presence of associated injuries. Stable fractures (Type I) are usually managed non-surgically with a rigid cervical collar or halo vest immobilization for a specific duration. Unstable fractures (Type II and III) may require surgical intervention to achieve realignment and stabilization of the C2 vertebra. Surgical options include anterior cervical fusion, posterior fixation, or a combination of both. Incorrect Options: Option B - Jefferson's Fracture: Jefferson's fracture is a fracture of the ring of C1 vertebra (atlas) caused by axial loading forces. It is characterized by fractures through the anterior and posterior arches of

questions.question: Identify the carpal bone that is most commonly fractured after fall on an outstretched hand .
questions.explanation: base of the thumb. It is susceptible to fractures when a person falls on an outstretched hand because of its position and the forces transmitted through the wrist during such an impact. Scaphoid fractures are common and can cause pain, tenderness, swelling, and limited wrist motion. It is important to diagnose and treat scaphoid fractures promptly, as they have a higher risk of complications such as nonunion (failure of the bone to heal) or avascular necrosis (loss of blood supply to the bone). Incorrect Options: Option B - Pisiform: The pisiform bone is a small bone located on the ulnar side of the wrist, anterior to the triquetrum bone. While fractures of the pisiform bone can occur, they are less common than scaphoid fractures after a fall on an outstretched hand. Option C - Lunate: The lunate bone is located in the center of the proximal row of carpal bones. Although it can be involved in wrist injuries, fractures of the lunate bone are less common than scaphoid fractures in cases of a fall on an outstretched hand. Option D - Hamate: The hamate bone is located on the ulnar side of the wrist, distal to the pisiform bone. While fractures of the hamate bone can occur, they are less common than scaphoid fractures after a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.question: Which of the following options is not linked to Sprengel deformity?
questions.explanation: heart is situated on the right side of the chest instead of the left. While dextrocardia is a distinct condition, it is not typically associated with Sprengel deformity. Incorrect Options: Option A - Diastematomyelia: (Associated) Diastematomyelia refers to a condition in which the spinal cord is split into two parts (bifid) by a bony or fibrous spur. Diastematomyelia has been reported in association with Sprengel deformity, suggesting a potential link between the two conditions. Option B - Klippel-Feil syndrome: (Associated) Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae in the neck. It is commonly associated with Sprengel deformity, among other skeletal anomalies Option D - Congenital scoliosis: (Associated) Congenital scoliosis is a spinal deformity that is present at birth and results from abnormal vertebral development. It has been reported in association with Sprengel deformity, suggesting a potential relationship between the two conditions. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The following images A and B show?
questions.explanation: condition where the flexor tendon is torn or avulsed from its insertion at the DIP joint, usually resulting from forcefully extending the finger while it is flexed. Baseball finger , also known as a mallet fracture , involves a fracture at the DIP joint caused by a sudden forceful impact to the tip of an extended finger. Image A represents jersey finger, and image B represents baseball finger. Incorrect Options: Option A - Mallet finger & Jersey finger : Mallet finger refers to a condition where the extensor tendon is torn at the DIP joint, leading to the inability to extend the finger fully. Option B - Boxer fracture & march fracture : Boxer fracture typically refers to a fracture of the metacarpal bone in the hand, specifically the neck of the metacarpal, usually resulting from a punch or direct trauma. March fracture refers to a stress fracture of the metatarsal bones in the foot. Option C - Mallet finger & boxer fracture : Mallet finger involves a tear or avulsion of the extensor tendon at the DIP joint, causing the inability to extend the finger fully. Boxer fracture refers to a fracture of the metacarpal bone in the hand. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the condition known as "painful arc syndrome"? joints. 120 degrees of shoulder abduction. of the body.

options.A: A condition in which joint stiffness lasts for more than 30 minutes in the morning, affecting multiple
options.B: A condition characterized by localized, sharp pain at the site of an injury or inflammation.
options.C: A condition where pain is experienced during a specific range of motion, typically between 60 and
options.D: A condition marked by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas

questions.explanation: typically between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction. between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction: Painful arc syndrome, also known as "subacromial impingement," is characterized by pain during a specific range of motion, usually between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction. This condition often occurs due to compression or impingement of structures in the subacromial space, such as the rotator cuff tendons, as the arm is raised. Incorrect Options: Option A - A condition in which joint stiffness lasts for more than 30 minutes in the morning, affecting multiple joints: This option does not accurately describe "painful arc syndrome." Joint stiffness in the morning for more than 30 minutes is typically associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, not painful arc syndrome. Option B - A condition characterized by localized, sharp pain at the site of an injury or inflammation: This option describes localized pain at the site of an injury or inflammation, which can be associated with various musculoskeletal or traumatic conditions but is not specific to painful arc syndrome. Option D - A condition marked by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body: This option describes fibromyalgia, a condition characterized by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body. It is a different condition unrelated to painful arc syndrome. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following fractures is most prone to non-union?
questions.explanation: proximal portion (near the base) of the scaphoid are notorious for their high risk of non-union. Non-union refers to the failure of a fracture to heal properly, resulting in persistent pain, limited function, and potential complications. The blood supply to the proximal scaphoid is relatively poor, making it susceptible to delayed or inadequate healing. Incorrect Options: Option B - Inter-Trochanteric: Inter-trochanteric fractures refer to fractures of the femur in the region between the greater and lesser trochanters. These fractures generally have a better healing potential compared to proximal scaphoid fractures. Option C - Distal Radius: Distal radius fractures are common fractures of the forearm near the wrist. While they can be challenging, with appropriate treatment, they usually have a good prognosis and a lower risk of non-union compared to proximal scaphoid fractures. Option D - Talar Neck: Talar neck fractures involve the neck of the talus bone in the foot. These fractures can be complex and have various degrees of blood supply compromise. While they carry a risk of complications, including non-union, the proximal scaphoid fracture is generally considered to be at a higher risk of non-union. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: The diagnosis of the given image
questions.explanation: refers to an abnormal movement or separation of the scaphoid and lunate bones, which are two of the carpal bones in the wrist. This instability can be caused by injury or ligamentous damage, leading to improper alignment and movement of these bones. Based on the given image, if there are specific features or signs indicating scapholunate instability, this would be the correct option Mechanism of Injury- Fall on an outstretched hand- Repetitive wrist trauma or overuse Clinical Presentation; Wrist pain or tenderness Swelling or instability in the wrist Signs of chronic instability may include a "dinner fork" deformity or widening of the scapholunate joint Physical Examination Scaphoid shift test: Palpable "clunk" or abnormal movement of the scaphoid bone with ulnar deviation and wrist flexion Watson test: Painful clunk or subluxation of the scaphoid during radial or ulnar deviation of the wrist Terry Thomas sign: Increased scapholunate space on radiographic imaging, indicating abnormal alignment between the scaphoid and lunate bones Radiographic Evaluation X-rays: Routine radiographs may reveal widening of the scapholunate joint space (>3mm) on a lateral view (Terry Thomas sign) Incorrect Options: Option B - Lunate Injury: This option suggests an injury specifically to the lunate bone in the wrist. While a lunate injury can occur, it is not the most accurate description based on the given information or image. Option C - Distal Radioulnar Joint Instability: Distal radioulnar joint instability refers to instability of the joint between the radius and ulna bones in the forearm. It does not specifically relate to the diagnosis of lunate instability depicted in the image. Option D - Wrist Dislocation: Wrist dislocation refers to a complete displacement

questions.question: A 25 year old man fell down while running. He tried to sustain the fall on his elbow resulting in the injury shown below. What will be the appropriate management of the following fracture ?

options.C: Close reduction with Tension band wiring
options.D: Immobilization of elbow, Above elbow plaster slab with 30 degree flexion

questions.explanation: Immobilization of the elbow, Above the elbow plaster slab with 30-degree flexion is the correct answer. Given here is the Xray of Fracture of the Olecranon. This is usually seen in adults. It results from a direct injury, as in a fall onto the point of the elbow. Pathoanatomy - The proximal fragment may be pulled proximally by the attached triceps muscle, thus creating a gap at the fracture site. The fracture may be one of the three types. Type I : Crack without displacement of fragments. Type II : Clean break with separation of fragments. Type III: Comminuted fracture. Treatment: It depends upon the type of fracture: Type I: A crack without displacement is treated by immobilising the elbow in an above-elbow plaster slab in 30 degree of flexion After 3 weeks the plaster is removed and elbow exercises begun. Type II: A clean break with separation of the fragments is treated by open reduction and internal fixation using technique of/tension-band wiring is not possible to keep the fragments together in the plaster alone because of the constant pull exerted by the triceps. Type III: A comminuted fracture, if not separated, is treated in a plaster: slab as in type-1, but if the fragments are separated/tension-band wiring

questions.question: Three point bony relationship has a diagnostic value in:
questions.explanation: specific landmarks in the elbow joint: the capitellum , the radial head , and the olecranon process. When these three points are aligned properly, it indicates that the elbow joint is in its normal anatomical position. In the context of elbow fractures, assessing the three-point bony relationship is crucial in determining the presence of a fracture and evaluating its displacement or dislocation. Any disruption in the alignment of these three points may indicate a fracture or joint injury. Incorrect Options: Option B - Monteggia Fracture: A Monteggia fracture is a specific type of forearm fracture-dislocation that involves a fracture of the ulna shaft and dislocation of the radial head. While it affects the elbow joint, the diagnostic evaluation of a Monteggia fracture is typically based on the fracture pattern and the dislocation of the radial head, rather than the three-point bony relationship. Option C - Galeazzi Fracture: A Galeazzi fracture is another forearm fracture that involves a fracture of the radius shaft with associated dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ). Similar to the Monteggia fracture, the diagnostic evaluation of a Galeazzi fracture focuses on the fracture pattern and the DRUJ dislocation, rather than the three-point bony relationship. Option D - Colles' Fracture: Colles' fracture is a type of distal radius fracture characterized by a fracture of the distal end of the radius, typically resulting from a fall onto an outstretched hand. The diagnosis of Colles' fracture is primarily based on the clinical presentation, physical examination findings, and radiographic evaluation, such as X-rays. The three-point bony relationship is not specifically utilized for diagnosing Colles' fracture. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 6-year-old child complaining of pain and swelling is suspected with supracondylar fracture of right hand (Undisplaced) . X-ray of right elbow was not significant. What is the next best step in this case?

options.A: Compare with X-ray of left hand
options.B: Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab (90 degree flexion)
options.C: Closed reduction with K wire fixation Cast

questions.explanation: Supracondylar fractures of the humerus are common injuries in pediatric patients. These fractures occur just above the elbow join t and can result in pain, swelling, and deformity of the affected arm. The initial evaluation typically involves an X-ray of the elbow to assess the fracture. In this case, if the X-ray of the right elbow is not significant(undisplaced), Therefore, the next best step would be Immobilisation and above the elbow plaster slab(90 degree flexion). Incorrect Options: Option A - Comparing with X-ray of the left hand: Comparing the X-ray of the right hand with the X-ray of the left hand may be helpful in certain situations to assess for any asymmetry or differences in bone structure. However, in the case of a suspected supracondylar fracture, comparing with the X-ray of the left hand alone may not provide sufficient information to confirm or manage the fracture. Option C - Closed reduction with K wire fixation cast: This is done in Displaced fractures Option D - Cast: Applying a cast alone without closed reduction may not be appropriate for managing a suspected supracondylar fracture. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A Post-menopausal women slipped and fell down on an outstretched hand in the washroom. X-ray of her distal forearm is given below. Diagnose the following condition?
questions.explanation: to decreased secretion of estrogen from ovaries. Women suffering from osteoporosis are prone to Colles fracture, which is a type of wrist fracture. This type of fracture usually happens after falling on an outstretched hand. The given x-ray shows fracture of the distal end of radius at cortico- cancellous junction, hence, Colles fracture is the correct choice. Fracture Name Characteristic Findings Sites Involved Special History Colles' Fracture Dorsal displacement of the distal radius Distal radius Falling on an outstretched hand Smith's Fracture Volar displacement of the distal radius Distal radius Falling on a flexed wrist Monteggia Fracture Proximal ulnar shaft fracture with radial head dislocation Proximal ulna, radial head Direct blow to the ulna or forearm Galeazzi Fracture Distal radial shaft fracture with distal radioulnar joint dislocation Distal radius, radioulnar joint Fall on an outstretched hand with an ulnar deviation Incorrect Options: Option B - Montaggiea fracture: The Monteggia fracture is the

questions.question: Assertion: Proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis Reason : Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end assertion E. Both assertion is and reason are false

options.A: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
options.B: Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is correct not the correct explanation for the
options.C: Assertion is true, but the reason is false
options.D: Assertion is false, but the reason is true

questions.explanation: the assertion necrosis. This means that the blood supply to the proximal pole is compromised, leading to tissue death. The reason given is that the blood supply to the scaphoid bone is retrograde, meaning it flows from the distal end (near the wrist) towards the proximal end (closer to the forearm). This retrograde blood supply makes the proximal pole more vulnerable to avascular necrosis as it receives blood last. The reason provided in the statement correctly explains why the proximal pole of the scaphoid is more prone to avascular necrosis. The retrograde blood supply pattern makes this region of the bone more susceptible to ischemia and subsequent necrosis. Incorrect Options: Option B - This option suggests that both the assertion and the reason are true, but the reason is not the correct This option states that the assertion is true, but the reason is false: However, the reason is true and provides a valid However, the assertion is indeed true, as supported by the high incidence of avascular necrosis in the proximal pole of the scaphoid. Option E - This option states that both the assertion and the reason are false: However, both the assertion and the reason are true and supported by clinical evidence. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: All of the following statements are correct about anterior shoulder dislocation except :

options.A: Recurrence rate is maximum if the patients age less than 20 years
options.B: Axillary nerve is most commonly injured
options.C: CT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion
options.D: Anterior shoulder dislocation is most common typeof shoulder dislocation,

questions.explanation: knowing the bony lesion: This statement is incorrect. While CT scans can provide detailed information about bony lesions in the shoulder, they are not typically the first-line imaging modality used for diagnosing anterior shoulder dislocation. The primary method for diagnosing shoulder dislocation is a combination of clinical evaluation, physical examination, and X-ray imaging. Incorrect Options: Option A - Recurrent rate is maximum if the patients age less than 20 years: This statement is correct. Anterior shoulder dislocation has a higher recurrence rate in patients younger than 20 years of age. This is due to the increased laxity of the joint structures and the higher likelihood of engaging in activities that can cause shoulder instability. Option B - Axillary nerve is most commonly injured: This statement is correct. The axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle and the skin over the shoulder, is commonly injured in anterior shoulder dislocations. The nerve can be stretched, compressed, or damaged during the dislocation, leading to temporary or permanent weakness or sensory loss. Option D - Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common type of shoulder dislocation: This statement is correct. Anterior shoulder dislocation is indeed the most common type of shoulder dislocation, accounting for the majority of all shoulder dislocations. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall on their outstretched hand. The X-ray image is given below. Identify the fracture.
questions.explanation: radial side of the wrist, and the scaphoid bone is one of the bones that forms its floor. A fall on an outstretched hand can cause a scaphoid bone fracture, most common in young adults, particularly males, and is often the result of FOOSH injury with the wrist in extension. Symptoms include tenderness and swelling in the anatomical snuffbox, pain with gripping or squeezing, and limited range of motion in the wrist. It has a high risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis. X-ray findings: visualization of the fracture +/- displacement soft tissue swelling and lateral displacement of the adjacent fat pads Incorrect Options: Option A - Colles Fracture: Colles fracture is a type of distal radius fracture where the distal fragment is displaced dorsally (backward). It occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hand with the wrist extended. The symptoms include pain, swelling, and deformity in the wrist.
